In classical logic, yes. ... And in intuitionistic logic, to speak intuitively, when you know that Aâˆ¨B is true, you know which one is true.

The idea of intuitionistic logic is that if you can prove a proposition P, it doesn't mean â€œP is trueâ€ (as it does in classical logic), but â€œI know how to prove Pâ€. When the proposition is of the form Aâˆ¨B, the way to prove Aâˆ¨B must either involve a proof of A or a proof of B, plus the information of which side you chose to prove. This is not true in classical logic, which has Aâˆ¨Â¬A as an axiom, which doesn't tell you which of A or Â¬A is true or how you'd prove it. The absence of this axiom, the excluded middle, is the defining feature of intuitionistic logic compared to classical logic.

Indeed, there is a rigorous way to say the above, in there is a modal companion of intuitionistic logic. This is a translation into classical logic + the S4 modal axioms, where you put a box (standing for "I know a proof of") in front of every subexpression of a proposition. So A âˆ¨ Â¬A becomes []([]A âˆ¨ []Â¬[]A). You can prove using the S4 axioms it is equivalent to put a box only in front of Â¬ and â†’, so you get []A âˆ¨ []Â¬[]A: "either I know a proof of A or I know a proof that there is no proof of A".
So if you know modal logic but not intuitionistic logic, this might help to give a bit of intuition :)

A more elementary way to do this is to consider any topology, say the usual one on the real line.

So false is interpreted as the empty set, true the whole set. Conjunction/disjunction corresponds to the usual intersection/union. And p -> q means (R \ p) âˆª q, and take the interior. Note that this ensures that every set you deal with is an open set.
So in this case Q, R are empty, and not P -> (Q or R) means the closure of P is the whole set, which by no means implies that P is the whole set.
